job_title: Resource Hub Program Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Health Package, Pension, Good pay, Excellent work environment
cons: I have not found any cons

review_title: Make a difference in a supportive environment
pros: Many people have worked at the organization for a very long time. Many things to like about working here including friendly staff supportive management and dedication to our mission.
cons: The hybrid work arrangement is appreciated but some positions could be done fully remote.

pros: This is an amazing company to work for as they offer support to prevent burnout that many are faced with trying to service so many of the participants we serve to the maximum level . Pay and room for advancement is very quick and never an issue with paycheck . Love the fact that prior to the holiday off you get off early and there are monthly team building meetings to engage with other staff in a relaxed setting .
cons: Burnout , High needs participants and heavy documentation

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Richardson, TX
pros: Forced teamwork and wonderful patients.
cons: Incredibly toxic atmosphere. People that work here have been here for 15 to 20 years. If you come in and attempt to join the team they push you out. They would rather hire agency than keep good staff.

job_title: Enhanced Case Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
After the first few months there is plenty of autonomy to get the job done. The job becomes a lot more default if that free range is taken away. 
Plenty of engaging interest people to work with. 
There are company cars to use.
cons:
Paper work is inevitable however, administration puts paperwork before service. 
Quotas are regular
Emotionally challenging dealing with cases.

pros: Multiple roles and varying scope of work
cons: Limited upward mobility and salary

pros: Great salary, not a lot of flexibility, wonderful coworkers
cons: Not a lot of flexibility

pros: Supportive staff, a lot of growth opportunity
cons: Some positions are grant funded and unclear if will get funding

job_title: Data and Information Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Foster a healthy work environment (even when remote!)
cons: The pay they are offering is low for the experienced applicant.

pros: They paid pretty well in comparison
cons: Dehumanizing-felt like a number at times

review_title: Contractor with Philadelphia Dept Public Health
pros: Very diverse opportunities and job roles. There is an ever changing need to manage the pandemic. Depending on the COVID case load there can be primarily remote work or on site work.
cons: Very diverse job roles and continually changing job requirements. PMHCC is the employer and they don't necessarily keep up with the dynamic job role. Any time you need "corporate" input they are disconnected from the reality "on the ground."

pros: Amazing PTO, bensfits, 403b, emphasize self care and employee wellness,
cons: Salary is low, management can be inconsistent at times as well

review_title: Fee for service job with fancy title.
pros: Flexible schedule, use of company vehicle, tuition reimbursement
cons: Units game, overbearing management and lack of room for growth while making you add tasks to your monthly requirements.

job_title: Clinical Project Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Health Benefits, all major Holidays off, 37.50 hr work week, academic reimbursement, non-profit
cons: HR, annual raises minimal if any (not based on performance evaluation)

job_title: BHRS Case Manager in Newtown, PA
pros: The Co workers were great.
cons: Low pay never any raises.

review_title: Fine but not a forever job
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Allows employees to work for the City of Philadelphia without meeting civil service and exempt position requirements
cons: Unclear who to contact when and communication can be poor

job_title: Human Services Incident Response Planner in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The team is the best; it's small, but they are all excellent people. There is flexibility in the work hours. There is a lot to do so you shouldn't get bored! There are lots of training opportunities so take advantage. My biggest advice is to take initiative on projects you're really interested in; the supervisor is very supportive.
cons: There is a division between City workers and contractors who are paid by PMHCC. And, working for the government, there are politics of course! Overall I recommend it as a workplace though. My biggest challenge in this position was accepting ambiguity in my role; I do better with structure and consistency, so this was a learning experience for me.

pros: The pay is higher for the position than other non-profits, but you are going to work twice as hard for every cent
cons: Lack of consistency, lack of transparency, managers are not trained, promises at hiring are not met, administration has a strong "don't rock the boat" mentality and even as the boat is sinking they don't want to fix it if it means more work or makes them look bad. High turn over is not because of 'qualify of front line local talent' it's quality of Program Directors, middle management and maintaining stagnant employees for years due to comfort and not production value

pros: I like my team, the employees I interact with, the work that I do, the contributions I make, what the company does for the participants it serves and initiatives, groups and projects I'm involved in.  I have well-rounded, productive days.
cons: I personally don't have anything not-so-favorable to say. It's what you make it.  I focus on the right things.

pros: The cheese steak vendor on the corner of Broad and Samson
cons: BHSI has started what seems to be a fraternity; keep your head low, don't speak up, kiss rear ends  and you're good. Dare to ask questions, be treated like a human being, or care to be treated with respect and your blacklisted. You will never move up, be gaslighted, yelled at, coerced, threatened, and put down repeatedly. Employees are treated  like dogs- be good, sit and beg for a treat, or be kicked.

pros: I have worked at PMHCC for almost a year, and must conclude that PMHCC is a great place to work. The agency has excellent executive management, great benefits, and a relaxing environment.
cons: The turnover is significantly high among direct line staff including case managers, administrative staff, and middle management which can be contributed to low morale.

pros: You can get there at 8am, leave at 10am,  and still get paid for the whole day
cons:
1 - they severely under pay their employees ( unless you are a higher up, you get paid about 20-30,000 less than what you should be making). Your education doesn't mean anything here. Someone without a degree and someone a Master's can make the same salary - even with all of the qualifications to make more, you won't

2 - they'll hire you for one thing, but have you doing everything but (they'll justify it with the line in the job offer as "other responsibilities") then when you don't get your regular work done because you were doing the other responsibilities, you're written up

3 - don't try to move up in the company - there's no room for growth unless you come in as a manager, you're someones family (or special friend if you know what I mean), or you dumb your work on those under you - then you can get promoted (the people that actually do work get treated like the red headed strep children)

4 - pray that you don't have an issue with another employee. Due to employees being mixed between several organizations, HR will do nothing about your issues (mind you I was racially, sexually, verbally, and physically harassed by an employee who is known for this behavior but is protected because of their drug and alcohol issues and because they're a city employee). If you complain about anything negative said or done to you, you will be written up or sent to training while the aggressor is just talked to.

5 - they don't take well to change. None of the employees actually work (maybe one or two days out of the week, but the rest they goof off). If you work too hard or try to make the organization better, they will quiet you - whether that means firing you or writing you up

6 - drama is everywhere! You have to walk on eggshells when you talk to people here. No matter how nicely you say it or try not to offend them, if you say something they don't like or agree with, expect to be called into a meeting about how you conduct yourself at work. They hire a lot of people that are in rehab with drug and alcohol and have mental health issues (not saying people don't deserve a second chance or that having a mental health issues is a problem, but they hire people who are not ready to be rehabbed back into the work place and it creates issues). They will also protect their LGBT and elderly employees - even if they are the ones sexually harassing you and you kindly ask them to stop or tell them you're not interested. You will be written up for sexual harassment

job_title: Intensive Case Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Only apply if you really need a paycheck.
cons: Everything. Coercive Authority. Meaning they purposely use fear and intimidation tactics against front line staff. Unfortunately, you cannot trust any one in administration, but you won't want to because 99% of them are incompetent and mean spirited. Will work you as hard as they can and still tell you you're not doing enough. Will not promote you no matter how long you have worked there or your degree. The only way to move up is to be malleable and dim.

pros: Great coworkers - OK benefits -
cons: Management has no training and terribly unprofessional. There is no room for growth and forget a raise! Despite various issues with management, no change was made. Overworked - underpaid - undervalued. For your own work/life balance - AVOID.

pros: Benefits are good, salary is decent considering that it's social services, some individuals actually care about the work and clients
cons: Poor structure, poor decision making (management), humongous egos, people who are there just for a paycheck

pros: Lots of flexibility in scheduling .
cons: Management has you do things to benefit the agency but if you do them on your own your in hot water, horrible double standard.

pros: Salary, Flexible schedule, Clients, Christmas Parties
cons: on-call, units of services are too much in too little time, management , lots of paperwork with no time to do it, open took work home

pros: Open Door Policy from upper management
cons: Limited Resources to support clients

pros: Good Salary, decent benefits, location.
cons: Poor management, HR structure, confidentiality.
